stem: Consider two wires of equal length. One is made of copper and the other of manganin, and they have the same resistance. Which wire will be thicker?

options.A: The copper wire will be thicker.
options.B: The manganin wire will be thicker.
options.C: Both wires will have the same thickness.

solution_latex: \text{The question 'Two wires have equal length, one is made of copper and the other of manganin and they have the same resistance. Which wire here will be thicker between these two given wires?' (11.11) is presented. The resistance of a wire is given by $R = \rho L / A$, where $\rho$ is resistivity, L is length, and A is cross-sectional area. For the same resistance (R) and length (L), a wire with lower resistivity ($\rho$) must have a larger cross-sectional area (A) to compensate. Copper has a lower resistivity than manganin. Therefore, the copper wire will be thicker. Option A is correct.}
